Then, it reverses the list s to s[::-1], so the reversed version. 

Then, it's looking for elements in w (the counter) where the frequency is equal to the maximum frequency. Among those elements, it wants the one whose reversed list's index is the greatest. Because 's is reversed, the first occurrence in the original list from the end is the highest index in the reversed list. 

Wait, the code picks the element with the max frequency. If multiple elements have that max frequency, then among those, it chooses the one whose first occurrence in the reversed array (which corresponds to the last occurrence in the original array) is the furthest to the right (highest index). Then among them, the one with the highest index in the reversed array is selected, which would be the last occurrence in the original array.

Thus, code outline for this part:

struct Entry {

    char *word;

    int count;

    int first_reverse_index;

};

struct Entry *entries = NULL;

int entries_count =0;

for (int i=0; i < n ;i++) {

    int current_rev_index = i;

    int original_pos = n -1 -i;

    char *current_word = s[original_pos]; // s is the array of pointers (each strdup'ed)

    int found = 0;

    // check entries for this word:

    for (int j=0; j < entries_count; j++) {

        if ( strcmp(entries[j].word, current_word) ==0 ) {

            entries[j].count++;

            found = 1;

            break;

        }

    }

    if ( !found ) {

        // add new entry

        struct Entry new_entry;

        new_entry.word = strdup(current_word); // assumes current_word is a dup? 

        new_entry.count =1;

        new_entry.first_reverse_index = current_rev_index;

        entries = realloc(entries, (entries_count +1)* sizeof(struct Entry));

        entries[entries_count] = new_entry;

        entries_count++;

    }

}

Thus, this way, entries array holds all the unique words, their counts and their first occurrence in the reversed array (note first_reverse_index is the index in the reversed array where the element first appeared (i.e. when this element was the first occurrence when traversing the reversed array from first to end. )

Now, after that, we have all entries with:

- count of each word.

- their first occurrence's index in reversed.

 Iterate through the entries to find the entry with count == max_count and with the maximum 'first_reverse_index'.

Thus:

int max_count =0;

for each entry in entries, compute max_count as the maximum count.

Then, among entries with count == max_count, track the entry with largest first_reverse_index.

so:

int target_first_rev = -1;

char *best_word;

for( each entry in entries) {

    if ( entry.count == max_count) {

        if ( entry.first_rev_index > target_first_rev ) {

           target_first_rev = entry.first_rev_index;

           best_word = entry.word;

        }

    }

}

Thus that gives the desired word. 

Once best_word is found, output it, and free memory.

Thus, the steps for the code in C are:

- Read n.

- Read the next line, parse into an array of strings (s array).

- Compute the entries array as above.

- Find max count.

- Iterate entries to find the best entry.

- Print the best_word.

- Free all memory.

Now, putting all together:

The code steps:

1. Read n. Are leading spaces in the input?

Probably need to read the first line via fgets, then use sscanf to parse n. Or read with scanf("%d", &n), then consume any newlines via getchar().

2. Read the second line. 

Sample code steps:

First, handling buffer for the second line (required to read all the words). So code:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

int main() {

    int n;
    char line[100000]; // assume big enough.

    fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin); // read first line.

    sscanf(line, "%d", &n);

    fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin); // read second line.

    char *s[n]; // using VLA, which is not standard C, but for the sake of example. Alternatively, allocate with malloc.

    // Now parse the second line into tokens:

    char *token;
    char *save_p;

    int count =0;
    int buffer_SIZE = 100000; // might be enough

    token = strtok_r(line, " \t\n", &save_p); // split on whitespace.
    while (token && count <n ) {

        s[count] = strdup(token); 
        count++;
        token = strtok_r(NULL, " \t\n", &save_p);
    }
    if (count !=n ) { 
        // error, but maybe just proceed.
    }

    // Now process to build entries.

    struct Entry { 

        char *word; 
        int count;
        int first_rev_index;
    };

    struct Entry *entries = NULL;
    int entries_count =0;

    for(int i=0; i <n ; i++) {

        // reversed array's current index is i (0 to n-1).

        // the current element is s[ n-1 -i ]

        char *current_word = s[n-1 -i]; 

        bool found = false;
        for(int j=0; j < entries_count; j++) {

            if( strcmp(entries[j].word, current_word) ==0 ) {

                entries[j].count++;
                found = true;
                break;
            }
        }

        if (!found) {

            struct Entry new_entry;
            new_entry.word = strdup(current_word); // because current_word is s's pointer, which is allocated via strdup earlier.

            new_entry.count =1;
            new_entry.first_rev_index =i; // because first occurrence at this reversed index.

            entries = (struct Entry*) realloc(entries, (entries_count +1)*sizeof(struct Entry));
            entries[entries_count] = new_entry;
            entries_count++;
        }
    }

    // Now find max_count:

    int max_count =0;

    for(int i=0; i < entries_count; i++) {

        if ( entries[i].count > max_count ) {

            max_count = entries[i].count;
        }
    }

    // Now select entries with count == max_count and highest first_rev_index.

    int target_rev =-1;
    char *result_word; 

    for( int i=0; i < entries_count; i++ ) {

        if( entries[i].count == max_count ) {

            if( entries[i].first_rev_index > target_rev ) {

                target_rev = entries[i].first_rev_index;

                result_word = entries[i].word;
            }
        }
    }

    // print result_word.

    printf("%s\n", result_word);

    // Free all allocated memory:

    for( int i=0; i <n; i++) {
        free(s[i]); // because allocated via strdup.
    }

    // free entries array:

    for( int i=0; i < entries_count; i++) {
        free(entries[i].word);
    }
    free( entries );

    return 0;
}

But let's adjust the code steps in that way.

Rewriting code:

    #include <stdio.h>
    #include <stdlib.h>
    #include <string.h>

    int main() {

        int n;
        char line[100000]; // big enough?

        // Read first line for n:

        fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);
        sscanf(line, "%d", &n);

        // Read second line:

        fgets(line, sizeof(line), stdin);

        // Split into words, store in s array:

        char **s = malloc(n * sizeof(char *));
        if (s == NULL) {

            return 1; // error handling.
        }

        char *save_p;
        char *token = strtok_r(line, " \n\t", &save_p);

        int count =0; 
        while (token != NULL && count < n) {

            s[count] = strdup(token);
            count++;
            token = strtok_r(NULL, " \n\t", &save_p);
        }

        if (count !=n ) {
            // invalid, but proceed.

            // might want to free?
            // for(int i=0; i < count; i++) free(s[i]);
            // free(s);
            // return 1;

            // proceed regardless.
        }

        // create Entries array:

        typedef struct Entry {
            char *word;
            int count;
            int first_rev_index;
        } Entry;

        Entry *entries = NULL;
        int num_entries = 0;

        // We process reversed array indices from 0 to n-1, which correspond to the reversed array's elements.

        // for each reversed index i:

        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { 

            int original_pos = n-1 -i; 

            char *current_word = s[original_pos]; 

            int found = 0;

            for( int j=0; j < num_entries; j++ ) {

                if( strcmp( entries[j].word, current_word) ==0 ) {

                    entries[j].count++;
                    found =1;
                    break;
                }
            }

            if (!found) {

                Entry new_entry;
                new_entry.word = strdup( current_word );
                new_entry.count =1;
                new_entry.first_rev_index = i; // the reversed index where first encountered.

                // allocate new entries array:

                entries = realloc(entries, (num_entries +1)* sizeof(Entry));

                entries[num_entries] = new_entry;
                num_entries ++;
            }
        }

        // Now find max count:

        int max_count =0;

        for( int i=0; i< num_entries; i++) {

            if( entries[i].count > max_count )
                max_count = entries[i].count;
        }

        // Find the entries with count == max_count and max first_rev_index;

        int best_rev =-1;

        Entry best_entry; // only need the first word? Or track the word.

        // Initialize result as first?

        char *result = NULL;

        for (int i=0; i < num_entries; i++) {

            if ( entries[i].count == max_count ) {

                if ( entries[i].first_rev_index > best_rev ) {

                    best_rev =entries[i].first_rev_index;

                    result = entries[i].word; 

                }
            }
        }

        // Now output:

        if (result !=NULL ) {

            printf("%s\n", result);
        } else {

            // This should not happen.

            printf("No result\n");
        }

        // Free all memory:

        // first, release s array:

        for( int i=0; i < n; i++ ) {
            free(s[i]);
        }

        free(s);

        // free entries' words and the entries:

        for( int i=0; i < num_entries; i++ ) {

            free(entries[i].word);
        }

        free(entries);

        return 0;
    }
